instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00034: What is 820-00034? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4L: What is PM_SLP_S4L? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4L, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message: USB on but no USB activity...where to start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?
Also check <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> and L7110/20 voltage.

threads.message:

<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> 3.3V
 L7110/20 1.7V

You should try known good BIOS.

<SIGNAL>FET_EN_P12V_S5</SIGNAL>-25V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
Do you note drop pulse at <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL> when first LED goes off?
You should change <TRANSISTOR>Q6970</TRANSISTOR>, just in case.

AON7402/08 and many other should work; not from Apple stuff.

Just try making a bypass D-S on it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message: It is controlled by <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, which is created from the power good signals of various power supplies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> 0v can be the problem?
i dont find the problem..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> requires various voltages, from S3 and even S0 state.

If <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses (when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>), then S3 voltages must pulse too.
If first LED (S5) goes off/on when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, SMC may detect some short/overcurrent on a secondary power supply.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
i have just the s5(pp3v3-pp5v..) voltage, other V rails are 0v, no shorts on the rails..
what produce the other voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
If S5 voltageas are steady, first LED must not blink.
S3 voltages may try to appear [B][U]IF[/U][/B] <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses; you must check them for pulse at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
S5 and 1st led are stable until I’m press the power button, then when I leave the power button the led shut off for 1sec and on again.
Pulse when I trigger power button?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
If LED1 blinks, then S5 state is not stable.
Check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, when pressing power button.
Use J5120 pads, instead of power button.

Be sure <SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL> is steady, not pulsing.

[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL> 13v stable

If you can't replace <TRANSISTOR>Q6970</TRANSISTOR>, then maintain the bypass.
Be sure no short on any secondary power supply.

I doubt you can heat something with such resistance value.
But you can try; sometime the bad IC can enter in thermal avalanche.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
Very strange; L7650 shouldn't have voltage at all, if missing EN2 at <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.
Check all <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> related components at <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> area.
May need to change <TRANSISTOR>Q7650</TRANSISTOR>/55.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
O.K there is a update..
<TRANSISTOR>Q7610</TRANSISTOR> was short on <SIGNAL>REG_PHASE_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> i was replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7610</TRANSISTOR> no there is no short.
no light, <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL> 3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
You've said to had steady <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>; why did you change <TRANSISTOR>Q7610</TRANSISTOR> then?
Is not possible to get correct L7610 voltage, if <TRANSISTOR>Q7610</TRANSISTOR> was bad.
Good <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> implies <SIGNAL>P12V_S5</SIGNAL> was also good.
Now you lost <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL>; not sure what you did...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message: i know, i was just check voltage at <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> area and then the light was off and there was a short on <TRANSISTOR>Q7610</TRANSISTOR> i was replace it and now this is the situation..no light and <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL> is 3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message:
NEVER touch the pins to mmeasure voltage on QFN chips?
Use surrounding components as test points.

You've made short between some <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> pins and <TRANSISTOR>Q7610</TRANSISTOR> got burnt.
Now <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> is probably damaged; maybe other adjacent components too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2 led on, fan on, no chime/screen
threads.message: i was replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> all the surrounded components look o.k...where to start?

L7650 - 150

threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is controlled by SMC.
However, sometime PCH can block SMC to work correctly.
